stream_context.summary: Kaze works on the paper/craft-themed level, focusing on brainstorming and implementing ideas for Yoshi Coin objectives. This involves designing a new 'Thimble Shy Guy' enemy from scratch, planning NPC missions, and refining level geometry. He also spends time rebalancing the spin jump mechanic to be less powerful and discusses his custom lighting/shader system for the N64.

development_findings.summary: Kaze identified the spin jump as an overpowered mechanic that broke level design by allowing players to scale walls, prompting a significant nerf.
development_findings.quote: I think the spin jump is cool, but it's way too strong... it is way too broken, like you can climb way too high with it.

development_findings.summary: The spin jump was redesigned from a height-gaining move to an aerial stall, intended to give players a recovery option and a sense of security rather than a climbing tool.
development_findings.quote: Yeah, now it doesn't really gain you height, but it lets you stall in the air a lot better. I kind of like that.

development_findings.summary: Kaze has implemented a custom lighting effect for the N64 that creates a reflective shine on materials like styrofoam. He is unfamiliar with standard industry terminology but understands the underlying principles of calculating light reflection relative to the camera.
development_findings.quote: I don't know the name of it, but I know how to program it. Specular map. I don't know if that's the right word... I found out that what I wanted wasn't actually a normal map.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is actively monitoring performance, testing the high-polygon paper level on actual N64 hardware and expressing surprise at its acceptable framerate.
development_findings.quote: There's 88,000 triangles in this level, but it's because of the text. Without the text it's 7,500 right now... Oh, they're actually using boots. And the framerate is not completely atrocious. I thought this was going to run a lot worse.

development_findings.summary: The 'blocky' and 'gaudy' appearance of the paper level, which some players have criticized, is an intentional design choice to support the crafted, cardboard aesthetic.
development_findings.quote: I think it has to look blocky for the effect to work. And it has to have pretty bright colors.

development_findings.summary: The decision to add Shy Guys was driven by the thematic connection to the game's title and inspiration, 'Yoshi's Island'.
development_findings.quote: This is Yoshi's Island. We need Shy Guys.

development_findings.summary: Kaze rejected the idea of a scissor-based enemy because it's a tool, not a creature, which violates his vision for the craft world's inhabitants.
development_findings.quote: A scissor enemy is lame. Scissor enemies don't fit... It's a tool. I think it's not the way I envisioned this to go.

development_findings.summary: The design direction for enemies in the craft level is to create creatures made of art supplies, such as cardboard Thwomps and toilet-paper-roll Spindles.
development_findings.quote: We have these thwomps and womps made out of cardboard and we have spindles as well. That's very good. That's how I want this to go.

context_findings.summary: Kaze acknowledges he is not allowed to charge for the game due to its nature as a ROM hack. He speculates on a free-to-play with cosmetics model if it were permissible.
context_findings.quote: If I was allowed to, maybe I would. Actually, what would I do if I was allowed to charge for this game? Probably release the base game for free and then you could buy a skin or something.

context_findings.summary: Kaze states he will not specifically design game mechanics to cater to speedrunning techniques or exploits, though he doesn't mind if they emerge naturally.
context_findings.quote: I'm not making changes specifically just so you can back amuse. If you can back amuse, that's a great. I enjoyed it as well, but I'm not going to cater to that.

context_findings.summary: Kaze has noticed a specific user consistently disliking his videos and seems amused by it, viewing it as a milestone.
context_findings.quote: I have also taken notes that I think we have our first real hater, which is news for me. There's one person disliking every video I upload like two minutes after I upload it. So this is exciting.

context_findings.summary: The project has a strict design pillar to only include characters, themes, and mechanics that existed in the N64 era or are original creations, avoiding post-N64 Nintendo IP.
context_findings.quote: We're not referencing anything Nintendo made up for like 1996 or after 2001, whenever the last N64 game released... We're also not adding anything that was invented after Nintendo 64 unless we invented it ourselves, basically.

biobak.summary: Kaze mentions that Biobak is nearing completion on a 'dummy' model, though the nature of the model is not specified.
biobak.quote: Biobak is almost done, I think.

biobak.summary: Biobak was responsible for replacing placeholder art of newer enemies with assets that fit the game's N64-era aesthetic.
biobak.quote: I'm pretty sure we swapped those out... I'm pretty sure Biobak swapped those out.

badub.summary: Kaze is waiting for Badub's music for the paper level and hopes for a dynamic score that adapts to the player's location within the level.
badub.quote: I'm gonna see what music Badub is gonna come up. Ideally I'm gonna have a music that changes depending on which biome of the level you're in.

zeina.summary: Zeina plans to create hand-drawn cloud assets for the paper level, influencing Kaze to not spend too much time on his placeholder versions.
zeina.quote: Zeina wants to draw in clouds anyway, so I'm attaching them right now.

zeina.summary: Kaze mentions Zeina is actively working on an asset during the stream, indicating a close, real-time collaboration.
zeina.quote: Zeina is working on it right now. It's not finished.

key_stories.title: Nerfing the Spin Jump
key_stories.summary: Kaze identified that the spin jump was breaking his level design by being too powerful. He deliberately nerfed the move, changing its function from a height-gaining exploit to a defensive aerial stall to give players security without trivializing challenges.
key_stories.challenge: The spin jump was too powerful, allowing players to easily scale vertical surfaces and break the intended platforming challenges.
key_stories.process: Kaze noticed the move was 'oppressive on the whole game's design' while testing. He experimented with changing its velocity and controls, ultimately deciding to reduce its height gain and horizontal movement to transform its core function.
key_stories.outcome: The spin jump was rebalanced to function as an aerial stall for recovering from missed jumps, rather than a tool for gaining height. This preserves level design integrity while still offering players a safety net.
key_stories.key_quote: I want this to be a very slow thing, that you kind of like do not want to use, but that gives you a feeling of security when it's available to you.

key_stories.title: The Birth of the Thimble Shy Guy
key_stories.summary: To create a thematically appropriate enemy for the craft level, Kaze decided to make a Shy Guy. After brainstorming materials, he settled on making it from a thimble, then went through a detailed process of modeling and texturing to give it a unique, bumpy metallic look that could be rendered on the N64.
key_stories.challenge: The paper craft level needed enemies that fit its unique aesthetic. A simple 'scissor enemy' was rejected as uncreative, and Kaze needed an idea for a creature made of craft materials.
key_stories.process: After deciding the level needed Shy Guys, Kaze brainstormed materials they could be made from. Settling on a 'thimble' idea from chat, he modeled the shape, drew a face on it, and then spent significant time experimenting with N64 texture and lighting tricks to simulate a bumpy, metallic surface, iterating until he was satisfied with the result.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze successfully designed and modeled a Shy Guy enemy made from a thimble. He iterated on the model to give it a bumpy, metallic sheen using a custom shader, creating a unique enemy that perfectly fits the level's theme and will be used in a Yoshi Coin mission.
key_stories.key_quote: What if we use one of those with like eyes drawn on? That would be perfect for a Shy Guy.

key_stories.title: Crafting the Yoshi Coin Missions
key_stories.summary: Faced with filling the large paper level with interesting objectives, Kaze decided to tie Yoshi Coins to unique NPC interactions. He brainstormed adding doodle versions of Peach and Bowser and new craft-based enemies like Thimble Shy Guys to create small, narrative missions for the player to complete.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze needed to place five Yoshi Coins in the large paper level in a way that felt purposeful and engaging, avoiding 'uninspired and boring' placements.
key_stories.process: Kaze reviewed the level layout, rejecting simple placements. He decided the best approach was to create small stories and tasks involving new NPCs. He brainstormed suitable Mario characters, planned out their craft-style appearance (e.g., doodles, cutouts), and mapped out where their associated missions would take place.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze developed several concrete ideas for Yoshi Coin objectives tied to new, craft-themed NPCs. These include rescuing a Peach doodle from Thimble Shy Guys, a small encounter with a paper cutout Bowser, and potentially using a pink Bob-omb to open a cannon.
key_stories.key_quote: The Yoshi coins are special interactions that we have in each level... this level doesn't have many NPCs that we can program interactions with. So we need to be creative and come up with things.
